author: David Whetstone
title: Landmark partnership signed between the Prado, Madrid, and Bishop Auckland Trust
text:
Landmark partnership signed between the Prado, Madrid, and Bishop Auckland Trust 14:04, 11 Oct 2016 Jonathan Ruffer's drive to regenerate Bishop Auckland has resulted in a deal with one of the world's most famous galleries Share Comments Get what's on news by email Jonathan Ruffer shakes hands with José Pedro Pérez-Llorca, chairman of the royal board of trustees of the Museo del Prado 
At first glance, an artistic link between the Bishop Auckland Trust and the Museo Nacional del Prado might look as unlikely as a footballing link between Bishop Auckland FC and Real Madrid. 
But the former link has just been formalised in a partnership deal between the Trust and the museum whose shorthand name, the Prado, is often uttered in reverential tones. 
The palatial museum in central Madrid houses one of the world’s most impressive art collections, including works by Goya, Velázquez, El Greco, Titian and Rubens. It is one of the world’s most visited attractions. 
But go on the Prado website and you will find prominence given to its new partnership with a town in County Durham – or at least the Auckland Castle Trust. John A Clarke Jonathan Ruffer at Auckland Castle 
The two organisations have come together to help to establish a centre of excellence for Spanish art, heritage and culture that will include a fellowship programme and a range of projects at the Trust’s Spanish Art Gallery which is due to open in 2019. 
The deal was signed at a ceremony in Madrid. 
Jonathan Ruffer, multi-millionaire philanthropist, art collector and chairman of Auckland Castle Trust, addressed the president of the Prado, José Pedro Pérez-Llorca, with reference to the possible effects of Brexit. 
He said: “The fabric which once held Europe and Britain together is now under threat, with no-one knowing quite how events will play out. 
“This small act of union between Auckland Castle Trust and the Museo del Prado is a powerful one and will set an international precedent for pan-European collaboration, demonstrating the immense benefits of continuing to pool our international resources, experience and expertise. Museo Nacional del Prado The Museo Nacional del Prado in Madrid 
“Together we plan to contextualise Auckland Castle Trust’s collections and bring greater understanding and merit to the genre of Spanish art and culture as whole. 
“The potential for this project is unprecedented and I am certain it will play a key role in putting Bishop Auckland and County Durham firmly on the international map.” 
What will both parties get out of the arrangement? 
The Museo del Prado will collaborate with the Trust on mounting exhibitions in the new Spanish Art Gallery. 
Auckland Castle Trust, meanwhile, will finance the Museo del Prado/Auckland Castle Fellowship, based in Madrid, which will allow for the development of projects common to both organisations. 
This arrangement will last initially for a year but with the option to extend it for up to three. 
While the Prado has a massive and priceless collection , County Durham has one of Britain’s most important collections of Spanish art. 
As well as the portrait series Jacob and his Twelve Sons by Francisco de Zurbur 
án, which has hung at Auckland Castle for some 200 years, there are notable works at the Bowes Museum, at Raby Castle and at Durham Cathedral and Castle. 
The new partnership follows confirmation that Auckland Castle Trust is also partnering with Durham University to launch the Zurbaran Centre for Spanish and Latin American Art which is due to open in 2017. 
Both these are part of the Trust’s £70m initiative designed to stimulate economic regeneration in Bishop Auckland.
